characters: A POOR-QUALITY VIDEO TAKEN AT A TALENT SHOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A “Tuscan"-style tract house in a remote, snow-covered fi The house looks very out of place, probably because this isn’t Tuscany. A deer grazes nearby. There’s a plastic “life-size” NATIVITY SCENE in the yard. BABY JESUS is discreetly tethered to the manger with a bi lock. Theft prevention.

dialogues.speaker: A POOR-QUALITY VIDEO TAKEN AT A TALENT SHOW.
dialogues.text: LAMB MANNERHEIM, 17, grips a microphone and paces the sta Lamb is pretty, but in an extremely modest, wholesome way Her clothes are dated, and she wears her long hair in an fashioned style. Think Walmart meets Little House on the Prairie. A homemade American Idol-inspired banner on the stage rea “Christ is OUR Idol! Youth Talent Night 2007.” Lamb takes this performance very seriously, even if it’s for friends and family. She holds the mic like a pro, fan her fingers and using moves she’s learned from TV. She sm and begins to sing in an unsteady, nervous voice. The song is “Place in This World,” a Christian anthem by Michael W. Smith.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (2007)
dialogues.text: The wind is moving But I am standing still A life of pages Waiting to be filled INT. MANNERHEIM HOUSE (LAMB’S BEDROOM) - MORNING We pan past a wall of family photos and mass-produced Christian art. A sticker that says “Real Women Eat Meat.” MONTANA BIBLE COLLEGE pennant. A cross. Lamb, now 21, is lying in bed. Faintly, as if underwater, hear the singing performance playing in another room.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (2007)
dialogues.text: A heart that's hopeful A head that's full of dreams (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 2.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (2007)
dialogues.text: But this becoming Is harder than it seems Lamb rolls over stiffly. We see her arms, covered with FL TONED COMPRESSION GARMENTS-- they’re like Ace bandages crossed with fingerless gloves. Lamb sits up, slowly and with effort. She’s a pretty youn woman. But her shoulders and neck are marred by PINK SCAR TISSUE. The scars could be covered with the right clothin but right now, every flaw is exposed. She winces in pain. Every day begins with pain.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ow. We INTERCUT with the video, which we can now deduce is playing in another room of the house.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (2007)
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a reason Roamin' through the night to find My place in this world My place in this world Lamb groans, stiffly swinging her legs out of bed. She wiggles her toes and reaches for a prescription PILL BOTT close at hand. Lamb dry-swallows four Vicodin pills in rapid succession- she’s a pro at this. We see that there’s a cup of HOT CHOCOLATE waiting for he the bed table. A CANDY CANE and some MINI-MARSHMALLOWS dissolve in the cocoa. Lamb moves the cup, revealing that napkin/coaster bears a handwritten message: “You R Still Pretty!!! XOxO Mom." Lamb wrinkles her nose at the cocoa.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ugh. Lamb exits the room and follows the sound of the talent s video to its source.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room is bedecked with religious Christmas item  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 3. MELANIE and DOUG MANNERHEIM, Lamb’s surprisingly young parents, are watching the talent show video on a gigantic plasma TV. MELANIE is an attractive woman with flowing curls and a sparkling bejeweled cross necklace. DOUG has spiky hair and a fitted button-down shirt with E Hardy-esque embroidery on it. As they watch the video, Melanie provides rapid-fire commentary:

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: This part I thought she did so well. You know that thing she does where she kind of takes off and makes it her own? That’s called a “run.” Doug has watched this many times before.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Lamb could have gotten a talent agent. I should have taken her to that open call in Missoula.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: That was a a long time ago. Lamb's annoyed voice interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Mom, you’re watching this again? Lamb has appeared in the living room entry, looking disheveled and vulnerable with her scars and compression garments on rare display. Melanie reacts as though she’s been caught watching porn.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: (startled) Oh! Lamb. You’re up early. Doug, where’s the clicker? She roots around for the remote control. Finds a couple o them in the couch. Flings them aside.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The small clicker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘Morning, Lamb.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Do you want your robe? The Mannerheim household is a modest one, and Melanie isn comfortable looking at Lamb uncovered. She tries to turn the tape, but only succeeds in TURNING UP THE VOLUME. Lam shouts over the song.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I asked you not to watch this anymore. I even hid the tape in Dad’s gun safe. Doug looks at Melanie. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: We all know the combination is the dog's birthday. On the TV: a young, stunning Lamb sings: My place in this world. My place in this world. Lamb stares numbly at her former self on the giant screen as Doug turns down the volume. MELANIE (CONT’D) Let’s get your robe. You must be freezing.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m a burn victim. I’m always freezing. Read the pamphlets again. An awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hey, did you see Mom made you a Candy Cane Cocoa?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I even put some midget marshmallows in there. (to Doug) Is it okay to say “midget” if it’s about a confection?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I'd say little. Mini. Lamb interrupts angrily. She gestures to the TV, where he younger self still sings.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 5.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Why the-- why the hell are you doing this to me? Both parents pause, surprised by her language. Lamb has n uttered the word “hell” in her life. (At least not in thi context.)

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Lamb!

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: This is bull. Now Doug and Melanie are shocked.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: That’s enough cursing.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: (to Doug) Maybe she didn’t take her medication yet. She has so much pain in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I took it, Mom. I took four.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: You mean you took one...

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Times four.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Lamb, you’re supposed to be tapering off the pills.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Well, Mom, you’re supposed to be “tapering off” the scrapbooks and photo albums and talent show videos from back when I didn’t look like Frankenstein. Now turn it off. (hesitating) Damn it! Melanie shuts off the TV and stares at her daughter. Curs is one thing. Taking the Lord’s name in vain is another entirely.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 6.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Lamb Grace Mannerheim. Did you just say the worst curse in my Tuscan mini-mansion?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Frankenstein was the doctor, not the monster. You’re an English major, honey. You should know that.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I was an English major.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You're still technically enrolled.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You might say I’m burned out on college, Dad. Get it? Ha ha.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: You were doing so good. What’s gotten into you lately?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (to Melanie) Could be the Devil.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Duh. Obviously. Lamb gives up, her shoulders sagging in defeat.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I’m really sorry. I’m just not feeling well today. Got my monthly bill.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: What bill? Lamb trudges off back toward her room.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m going to go practice my guest sermon, okay?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Let me know when you’re ready for hair and makeup. Melanie and Doug exchange glances as she leaves. This isn the Lamb they know.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 7. INT. LAMB'S ROOM —- MORNING Lamb sits on her bed. She wears a modest dress, a flowere headband and lace tights. Her hair is pulled up into one those pouf/braid combos commonly seen on fundamentalist Christian women. Melanie has a large professional tacklebox filled with makeup. She uses a puff to apply some type of cover-up po to Lamb’s scars.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: This is from our new line. It’s all- natural minerals from the earth. It covers everything. You know Shana Qualley’s mom? She has a lot of redness from, well, from drinking. I use this on her and she looks a lot better. Not good-- that would take a miracle-- but better. Lamb says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I really don’t like to talk about people. (finishing) There. You look radiant. Lamb looks at her neck and collarbones in the mirror. It’ not an improvement. We still see the scars.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Dr. Cha says I’m not supposed to put anything on there.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Lamb, it’s 100% natural. One of our representatives puts this on her four-year-old every day.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Why? Melanie is putting away her makeup tools. She closes the tackle box.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Do you feel ready to give your guest sermon?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Mm-hm  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 8.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: If you get nervous, just imagine Pastor Rick in his underwear.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) That won’t be necessary.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Let me just hear the beginning. Lamb sighs, dutiful.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: “My beloved family in worship. I stand here today as miraculous evidence of God’s healing grace...” Do I have to practice right now?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: No. Just remember: God’s counting on you. You can make a difference with what you say today. It’s like I always say, you can affect change in a small way and it makes a big ripple. Like a--

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Like a toot in the bathtub. I know.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: That’s right. She kisses Lamb’s “pouf.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mannerheim’s car pulls up to a GIANT MEGA-CHURCH COMP The vast parking lot is filling up with worshippers. The church's giant marquee-type sign reads: “WHY ‘TWEET’ SATAN WHEN YOU CAN ‘FOLLOW’ CHRIST?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mannerheim’s are bundled up in parkas and scarves. Melanie rolls down the window and peeks out at the overflowing parking lot.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy)

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Will you look at this clusterhug? I love seeing this many people come together in His name, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I think some of them just come for the smoothies. We see that one of the many entrances to the church superstructure says “GOD'S BOUNTY SMOOTHIES & COFFEE.”

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: We're lucky to belong to a church with amenities. The Catholics don’t have a juice bar.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: The Catholics get to drink the actual blood of Christ.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: They think that, don’t they? Aren’t our differences interesting? I'1l pray for them. Doug, park over by the gift shop. I want to pick up a new journal after church. (to Lamb) I’ve been writing.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Good for you, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I'm writing a little story about an old man and an old woman and their whole epic love story going back decades.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Sounds like The Notebook.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Um, it’s totally unlike The Notebook. I wouldn’t copy my own favorite book that I’ve read 100 times, would I? (then) Doug, there’s one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VAN from an assisted living home pulls into Melanie's chosen parking spot.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 10. MELANIE (CONT’D) (annoyed) God BLESS it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud CHRISTIAN HIP-HOP BAND plays. Two RAPPERS-- a whit guy and an Asian girl-- bust some rhymes.

dialogues.speaker: RAPPER
dialogues.text: Jesus, you're my savior. You made me like Xavier. Roberts. Your creation. You rule the nation!

dialogues.speaker: RAPPER
dialogues.text: I love Jesus like William love Kate. Jesus, you're my prince, let's set the date. Melanie, Doug and Lamb take their seats in the front row the massive auditorium. On the walls of the church, we see a few large POSTERS wi photo of a smiling Lamb. She wears a black dress with pea her neck and arms are creamy and scar-free. The posters say: LAMB MANNERHEIM SHARES HER INSPIRATIONAL STORY OF SURVIVAL. SUNDAY, DECEMBER 17, 10:00 SERVICE.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: The posters came out nice. I need one of those for my brag wall.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Is that the picture you sent them? Why did you send them an old photo?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: It’s the nicest photo we have of you. That reminds me, we need to go to the portrait studio as a family. We could wear matching outfits and jump in the air! (off Lamb’s dour look) Or we could sit nicely. Lamb is fixated on the poster.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I don’t look like that anymore. I looked like a Barbie. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 11.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now I look like a Barbie that got tortured with a lighter.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: First of all, you were never any kind of Barbie. You’re obviously a Skipper. She discreetly indicates Lamb’s small chest.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Honey, if I could crank your arm and make them grow, I would. Secondly, self-pity is unbecoming. You're getting better every day. People don’t even look anymore. We see a MOM and DAD trying in vain to keep their KIDS fr staring at Lamb. A LITTLE GIRL, who’s about 2, starts to point and cry loudly. MELANIE (CONT’D) That’s a tough age. They take their seats. As Melanie and Doug socialize with people seated around them, Lamb begins to NOD OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb WAKES UP, a bit dazed. PASTOR RICK, the young, hands dynamic leader of the congregation, is introducing her.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR RICH
dialogues.text: ...-And now, we have a very inspiring young lady who’s agreed to talk to all of you today. Lamb Mannerheim has been a member of our church family, since, well, since I was a kid! She’s been a valued youth evangelist, the valedictorian of her home school collective and a favorite performer in our music ministry. When we think of well- formed, righteous, feminine role models, we think about girls like Lamb. (clearing his throat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 12.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR RICH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As you all know, Lamb survived a tragic accident while she was away at Montana Bible College two years ago. As a community, we felt her pain and loss. But now, she’s miraculously back on her feet to share a courageous Christmas tale of faith and healing. Brothers and sisters...Lamb Mannerheim. Lamb stands up and makes her way to the podium. She gets STANDING OVATION from the appreciative crowd. We can see Pastor Rick CHECK HER OUT briefly (but inappropriately) as she takes the stage.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Thanks Pastor Rich. Good morning, everyone. I know you’re all expecting me to deliver testimony about the accident and how, through the grace of God, I recovered. But really, you were hoping to hear gory details about the crash. Like how I could smell myself burning, but I couldn’t feel it. On Melanie: her face falls. This wasn’t what they practic But Lamb remains calm, smiling, even serene.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Isn't that funny? I was in the parking lot of a Kroger, on fire, and as I laid there, all I could think about was my shoes. That they looked strange. “I don’t remember wearing clogs today. Oh. I didn’t. They’re regular shoes, but they’re melting. And, come to think of it, so am I.” The crowd begins to murmur. Lamb continues brightly.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, the accident was bad. But the surgeries-- those were even worse. Did you know they can take skin from your butt and put it on your back? And where does that leave your butt? (chuckling) I guess thongs are out of the question now! Sorry Pastor Rick.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 13. Now everyone is really uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But enough of that. What I’m really here to say today is that the horrible, unspeakable pain I endured didn’t strengthen my faith in the slightest. In fact, I’ve become an athiest. I’m here to share my new wisdom with you. Everyone, there is no God. Pastor Rick appears at her side, but she slaps him away.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t touch me. My skin grafts are very fragile. I could bleed all over our nice new alter carpeting and then you’d have to take up another collection! (to congregation) Another collection. You already tithe most of your income to this place. How’s that working out for you? Do the skate park and the putting green make you feel more righteous?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Lamb, stop! Get down from there!

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m not done yet, Mom. Almost. Okay, so I don’t believe in God. Here’s what I do believe: I believe in science. I believe in the doctors who were there when I woke up. I believe in opiates and morphine, which work whether you have faith in them or not. I’m willing to believe that the universe was created in an explosion, and that fish-creatures crawled out of the mud and evolved into human beings. And, in our next presidential election... (pause) I may vote for Obama. That does it. Chaos breaks out in the auditorium.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 14.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Before I’m forcibly removed from the stage, I want to say that I’m leaving Billings for a while. I’ve spent my entire life abstaining from earthly vices and drinking the smoothie of ignorance concocted by this very church. Tomorrow, I’m getting on a plane to Las Vegas, Nevada, where I plan to gamble, drink alcohol, and frolic with homosexuals-— Melanie seizes control of the podium. Feedback squawks as Melanie grabs the mic and interrupts in a shaky voice.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry, everyone. My daughter is still recovering.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) What? Mother, I’m radiant! Melanie is too close to the mic. Her voice booms in an unintentionally hilarious way.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Please pray for us.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Or don’t. The last time you prayed for me I wound up looking like this. Wah-wah!

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Let’s get you out of here. She reaches for Lamb, who lunges back toward the mic, pul her cardigan aside to reveal her shoulders. She shouts cheerfully into the mic.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: My shoulders look like turkey bacon! God who? As Melanie takes Lamb’s elbow and hustles her away from t podium, she accidentally hurts her daughter's skin.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ow. She collapses and grabs her elbow.  15.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Oh no! Baby, are you okay? The sound drops out. Lamb shouts a VERY BAD WORD. The forbidden curse echoes off the walls of the enormous church. A fitting climax to Lamb’s public rejection of Go Doug takes a long, uncomfortable sip from his “God’s Boun smoothie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb is sitting on the crowded Vegas-bound PLANE. She wea modest dress and looks bewildered and overwhelmed. A TEENAGE GUY, 17, stashes his stuff in the overhead compartment and climbs into the seat next to hers. He stares at the fingerless COMPRESSION GARMENTS on her a and hands as if they’re some cool accessory.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: Where’d you get those gloves? Lamb can barely hide her annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: The Mayo Clinic. (then) They're compression garments. Like big Band-Aids.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: Oh. Do you cut?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Do I what?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: Like, are you a cutter? Do you cut yourself on purpose, like with a razor blade or a knife?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No. The guy pulls up his arm to reveal a ladder of 4 or 5 sma pathetic red slashes. Scratches, barely.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: Check it.  Lamb is offended by these self-inflicted wounds.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You should be ashamed of that.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Because it’s disrespectful. That’s your arm. You are the earthly custodian of that arm and you choose to treat it like a whittling block?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: A block of wood that one whittles.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: It’s not my fault. My therapist says I have a textbook “Type D” personality.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: "Type D"?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: Depressed. It means you pretty much want to kill yourself all the time. Lamb considers this.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: When I feel “depressed”, I go fora bike ride in the sunshine or I play my flute or I read Scripture (catching herself) -- well, I don’t read Scripture since I renounced God, but the other two. Anyway, I would never cut my body. That seems counterintuitive if you’re trying to be of good cheer. The guy stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: Sunshine and the flute? Are you from that family on TV that has like 20 kids and is in a cult? 16.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 17.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I don’t watch TV. (quietly) Also, it’s not a cult. They’re just Baptists. A pause. The guy drums his fingers anxiously on the armre

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: I hate takeoff. I get so jumpy on planes.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: There’s pretty much zero chance this plane will go down.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: I know there’s all those statistics, like, safer than a car and stuff but...

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No. Factually speaking, the odds of this plane crashing are much lower than you realize. Like one in approximately ten trillion, since I’m on here.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: (scoffing) What, because you’re magic or something?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No. Because it never happens to anyone twice. The guy, realizing, stares at Lamb in awe.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Type D. (shaking her head) D for Dummy. My goodness. She takes a brand new copy of The Audacity of Hope by Bar Obama out of her bag, cracks the spine, and begins readin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teenage guy sleeps. Lamb is wide awake, bored with he book. She gazes out the window.  18. She turns to the personal IN-FLIGHT ENTERTAINMENT SCREEN the seatback in front of her. She presses “Movies.” Lots of options come up. Lamb scrolls past the family- friendly categories, determined to corrupt herself. She chooses a category called “Exclusive! Vegas-Inspired Movi to Get You in the Mood!” We see a selection of famous Las Vegas moves: The Hangove What Happens in Vegas. Leaving Las Vegas and then... Showgirls. If it’s possible for a person to blush at the sight of a movie title, Lamb does. The movie is aptly described as “The Cult Classic Erotic Thriller!” Lamb glances at her seatmate. Still sleeping. The aisle s is occupied by a senior citizen doing Sudoku. Tentatively, Lamb presses “Play” on Showgirls. She makes no one is looking and settles in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb is watching the infamous pool sex scene. Her brow is furrowed, as if she’s watching an interesting ritual from some foreign civilization. The teenage guy stirs. Lamb immediately leans forward and tries to turn off the movie.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: (dazed) Hm? (seeing) Whoa! All right! Lamb is wildly pressing the “home” icon on the touchscree It’s stuck on Showgirls, frozen in the land of violent po sex. TEENAGE GUY (CONT’D) What is this? Species? Lamb is mortified, but holds her head high.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Showgirls.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: I would not have thought you would choose this particular film.  19.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Well, I did. (primly) I love erotic thrillers. The guy cranes his neck to check out the screen

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE GUY
dialogues.text: Me too. Lamb looks away, but her eyes wander back to the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb moves through the airport, past the ding-ding-ding o slot machines and hordes of tourists. The whole place is decorated for Christmas and the mood is both festive and profane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb stands at the baggage claim and waits for her suitca She carries her flute in a black case. Three STRIPPERS from the same flight wait just behind her the crowd. They wear sweatsuits in contrasting pastels. STRIPPER #1 is a Latina beauty with hair down to her wais and 0% body fat. She stamps her feet dramatically.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: I need a smoke so bad. STRIPPER #2 is a tan, corn-fed blonde.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: You're making it worse by talking about it.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: Ladies, I got that feeling like I’m gonna bank this weekend. I’m gonna make six Gs.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: Nobody makes six Gs anymore. Not even feature girls.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: I know the economy sucks, but this bubble don’t break.  20. She does a few booty-pops. The girls giggle. STRIPPER #3 is a tough, short girl.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: If I even make one G, I’‘ll be happy. We keep coming out here for the weekends, but truth is, Vegas is as broke as Montana. (to Lamb) Hey, can you grab that big Louie for me? A LOUIS VUITTON suitcase is making its way around the carousel. It’s positioned in such a way that Lamb can rea it but the stripper can’t. Lamb isn’t sure what a “Louie” but she guesses.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: This one? She grabs the bag with difficulty and swings it over to i owner. The strippers see the scars on Lamb’s arm as she reaches forward.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: Girl, what happened to you? Stripper #1 is embarrassed by her friend’s rudeness.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: Lexus!

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: Looks like someone said they was gonna cut a bitch and actually did it. Damn. (by way of apology) You still cute, though.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: Yeah. She’s cute. She could probably get a day shift at the Lumberyard.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: The Lumberyard?

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: You know the Lumberyard in Helena? We work there. (then, aggressive) Yeah, I said it. There’s no shame in the game.  21.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Why would you be ashamed of that? Christ was a carpenter. The girls exchange glances and burst into peals of laught It’s not “mean girl” laughter, per se, but genuine surpri at Lamb’s dorkiness.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: We're not carpenters. The Lumberyard is a gentlemen's club.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Oh. Ah. You’d think I would have gotten that, since I just watched Showgirls on the plane. (whispering) I know all about what you do. An awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: STRIPPER
dialogues.text: Right. You got it all figured out. The girls shake their heads as Lamb reaches onto the bagg carousel and takes her childish pink suitcase. We see pee letters printed on the suitcase: GOING TO GRANDMA’S. Lamb extends the handle and walks away, rolling it behind with her head held high. The strippers watch, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb approaches the taxi stand, where a jaded ATTENDANT f down cars. Clutching her printed itinerary, she takes a d breath.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: One taxi, please.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Where you headed?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Um, the Planet Hollywood Resort?

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Play-Ho. Got it.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Planet Hollywood.  22. The attendant tosses her pink suitcase carelessly into th trunk of a waiting cab. It lands with a THUNK as Lamb mee protests.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, I have dishes in there. The man stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Why'd you bring dishes to Las Vegas? Lamb climbs into the back seat of the cab. She goes to bu up and discovers only a lap belt.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (to driver) Sir? Is there a shoulder belt?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (thickly accented) What, you want a baby seat too? Goo goo. The attendant slams the door shut and the cab squeals awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb admires the spectacular lights of the Strip from the back of the cab. Remembering Showgirls, she decides to as about a certain Vegas landmark.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. Where is the Stardust? The driver's accent and ethnic background are impossible place.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: The Stardust Hotel. Where they have the Goddess musical performance?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Stardust? That was, eh, bombed a few years ago. Blown up inside with dynamite. Big boom. Lamb has been raised to be very wary of terrorism.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 23.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Oh, no. (whispering) Was it Muslims?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Muslims? No, man! The guy who owned it blew it up with purpose so he could build a new hotel. What do you think I know about some terrorists? (then) Ah, I hate this Trop light. They're stopped at the intersection of Las Vegas Boulevar and Tropicana. It’s gridlock on every side.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Trop light?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Yeah, man. Tropicana. Longest light in town. The cab slows to a stop. Lamb looks out the window at the York, New York roller coaster and the Excalibur’s fake ca turrets illuminated overhead. She’s enchanted by the sigh

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Kind of looks like Disney World.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Disney World. Ha. That place? You ever been to Disney World?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No. I wasn’t allowed to, because the Disney Corporation supports the homosexual agenda.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Last night, in this cab, I have two gay guys getting married. I got no problem with it. As long as they keep their penis inside the blue jeans. I said, if I see some gay, I see some Doogie Howser bullshit, you're out! Here we are. He pulls over to the curb quickly, sending Lamb flying.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver takes Lamb’s pink suitcase out of the trunk. L nervously peels off a few bills from a conspicuously larg WAD OF CASH.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Thanks. Hey, you know how you said you weren’t allowed to go to Disney World?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Was the Disney Channel also forbidden?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Emphatically so.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Even The Wizards of Waverley Place?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Satanists. Lamb turns and walks toward the hotel with her suitcase a her flute. The driver looks down with surprise at the LARGE WAD OF M she’s handed him.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb walks into the hotel. She scans the room nervously. early in the evening. TOURISTS play craps and blackjack a wander around with drinks. The scene is relatively tame a even a little hokey. Lamb seems relieved.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Huh. It’s kinda like Branson. An OLD WOMAN pulls the lever on a cheesy branded slot machine. The machine discharges a few quarters.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 25.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No problem. She steps forward bravely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb, checked in, tucks her room key into her pocket. She about to walk to the elevator, but she pauses and goes in the hotel’s gift shop. Lamb takes a tacky, sparkly T-shirt off one of the racks. says “I (HEART) LAS VEGAS,” only instead of a heart, ther - nonsensically-- a pair of dice.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (whispering) “I Dice Las Vegas.” It doesn't look like anything Lamb would normally wear. B nothing about this night is normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb, now holding a SHOPPING BAG, waits for an elevator t take her up to her room. From where she stands, we can already hear some raucous shouting coming up the elevator shaft. The elevator doors open, revealing about 5 WET FRAT BOYS coming up from the pool area. They’re drunk and in variou states of undress. Think damp towels, tribal tattoos, steroidal acne and loud, booming voices.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: I swear, I only had a half a pill, but I’m rolling so hard.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: Dude, I’m flying. We should call those sluts from Tao and get an eight ball for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: Phenomenal, bro!

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: Phenomenal.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: Hey.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 26. The shouting and laughing stops abruptly when they notice Lamb standing there. Silence. Lamb primly steps into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The frat boys are trying to hold it together, but they’re making crazy expressions at each other and (barely) suppressing laughter. They don’t know how to respond to a pretty girl who’s been desexualized by injury. Finally, o of the guys talks.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Hello. One of the guys begins to crowd her in a creepy way. He strokes her ponytail. One of them whispers

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: Uh, where are you from? The other guys snicker. This is the equivalent of the hig school quarterback hitting on an ugly girl to make his friends laugh.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Chernobyl. Huh huh.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m from D.C.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m a federal agent. Drug enforcement.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: Oh really?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I just orchestrated a huge meth lab sting in Iowa. The place blew sky high. Messed me up pretty bad, as you can see. But I’m back in action. Vegas is my new beat. Lamb's voice is shaking, but she sticks to her story.  27.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I'm looking forward to making some arrests. The people here aren’t very discreet, so it should be easy! Plus, I’m a super-smeller. You know drug-sniffing dogs? I'ma drug-sniffing human. I’m accurate up to four yards, that’s how I got into the DEA. I beat out a golden retriever in tests.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: (to his friend) Hey, let’s get off here, man.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. We passed our floor. They begin stabbing buttons in a panic. The doors open on mezzanine level.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: This isn’t your level is it? This looks like a convention of Chicano attorneys. An easel-style SIGN welcomes people to the NATIONAL CONFERENCE OF CHICANO ATTORNEYS. Nevertheless, the frat guys all scurry off the elevator, failing to blend in with the crowd. Lamb exhales as the doors close. She closes her eyes. The encounter scared her more than she let on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb takes out her key card. We see a group of cute, happ SOMETHING GIRLS headed out for a night on the town. They down the hall toward the elevator, holding hands.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Wait, Zoe, this is your first time seeing Cirque? You're so gonna cry.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh my God, I know.  28.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Liz, those shoes are phenomenal. So phenomonal.

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: Phenomenal! Wistfully, Lamb watches them as they pass. She tries out word everyone her age is (over)using.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Phenomenal. Phenomenal. She slides her key into the door. The light turns green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a much nicer hotel room than we might expect a young small-town traveler to stay in. Lamb unzips her suitcase. There’s a BROKEN “FIESTAWARE” DISH on top of her neatly folded clothes. She sadly removes the pieces.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Shoot. There are three other dishes that are intact. Lamb remove them and carefully stacks them on the TV console. Then, she begins to hang up her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through frosted glass, we can barely make out Lamb’s silhouette. She stands in a big, square Vegas bathtub. He compression garments are hanging on the towel rack. Rather than normal showering sounds, we hear a trickle of water. Lamb is washing herself slowly and methodically. H hand clutches a bar for support. We see how her movement limited and that something as simple as bathing has becom complicated for her. She quietly sings, her voice echoing off the walls.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (singing) The wind is moving, but I am standing still...  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb slides a compression sleeve up her arm.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: A life of pages, waiting to be filled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb, now wearing her sequined Vegas T-shirt and her customary knee-length denim skirt, brushes her hair and slides her stocking-covered feet into pink flats.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Feels like I'm looking for a reason...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb rides down to the lobby with a group of shoddily dre TOURISTS. As always, she wears her cardigan, though the T shirt’s sequined logo is visible. She sings under her bre

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Roamin' through the night to find... The doors open.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My place in this world. My place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the elevator doors open, Lamb’s ears are suddenly assaulted with autotuned, bass-heavy hip-hop music. The m of the hotel has changed considerably. Shit is GOING OFF. Lamb walks through the casino, observing the chaos. A few hired DANCERS are working the pole next to a craps table. Lamb stares at their hard, flawless bodies as they writhe and gyrate, bored. A PREGNANT BRIDE in handcuffs and a light-up “penis tiara gets led through the lobby by her FRIENDS. Lamb’s eyes wi as the colorful penises blink at her, as if in code.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 30. In a nearby bar, a MIDDLE-AGED MAN plants his mouth at th bottom of an ice luge while someone pours vodka down the ramp.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: That doesn’t seem clean. At a centrally located casino buffet, TOURISTS scoop pile crab legs onto their plates. Even something as innocent a food seems to become excessive and wasteful in Las Vegas. A crab leg falls off the plate of a JOLLY FEMALE TOURIST.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, you dropped a...leg.

dialogues.speaker: CRAB TOURIST
dialogues.text: (to friend, ignoring Lamb) Ha! No, no, no, no Leslie. You’re on crack! You are legit smoking crack. Wait, that’s my phone.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: A crab was trapped and asphyxiated so that you might be nourished by its leg. The woman still isn’t listening. Lamb might as well be invisible. Finally, Lamb scurries over to the buffet area picks the leg off the floor. Immediately, a STERN BUFFET ATTENDANT rushes away from hi prime rib carving station and confronts Lamb.

dialogues.speaker: BUFFET ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Ma’am, the buffet is for paying customers, not scavengers.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (shocked) I wasn’t scavenging. She’s wasting food.

dialogues.speaker: BUFFET ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Oh, I saw the whole thing. The king crab leg hit the floor and you came scurrying out of nowhere like a dirty raccoon.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I did not scurry. These people are gluttons. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 31.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s like they think crabs come from a factory, rather than a delicate marine ecosystem. They have no respect for life.

dialogues.speaker: BUFFET ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Are you from PETA? Do you hate the circus and pony rides?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: What? No.

dialogues.speaker: BUFFET ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Are you one of those anti-abortion psychos?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I don’t think so...

dialogues.speaker: BUFFET ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: “Hookers for Jesus”?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I suppose I just think buffets are wasteful.

dialogues.speaker: BUFFET ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Please leave my carving station immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb walks down the street, dejected. She passes a NASTY LITTLE MAN handing out fliers for female escorts.

dialogues.speaker: NASTY LITTLE MAN
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas! Beautiful, sexy girls! Hot girls delivered to your room! Lamb plucks a flier from his outstretched hand. It says: GIRLS! NO BULL! A photo of a YOUNG BRUNETTE GIRL gazes ou Lamb. The caption reads: RYDER, 19. MASSAGE, ROLE PLAY,

dialogues.speaker: SHOWER, GREEK. ANYTHING GOES
dialogues.text: Lamb’s face falls. For some reason, she stuffs the flier her purse, even though it repulses her. She keeps walking and encounters a YOUNG CHRISTIAN EVANGE handing out RELIGIOUS COMIC BOOKS.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 32.

dialogues.speaker: EVANGELIST
dialogues.text: Jesus saves! Accept Christ as your Lord and Savior today! Christ died for your sins. Lamb looks at the young evangelist, seeing herself in his her hopeful gaze. The evangelist thrusts a book into Lamb hands. EVANGELIST (CONT’D) Here. This comic book contains the key to eternal life. The comic is called “Viva Las Satan?” The cover depicts a smirking DEVIL presiding over a poker table. Lamb takes o and examines it with an air of familiarity.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (holding up comic) Ah yes. A fine title from Salvation Press. I’m acquainted with this one. At the end, the gamblers all go to hell and learn that God’s love was the real jackpot. Oh, and Jews are vampires. The end. She hands the comic book back to the evangelist.

dialogues.speaker: EVANGELIST
dialogues.text: Oh. Are you saved?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Do I look saved?

dialogues.speaker: EVANGELIST
dialogues.text: Um, well, we’re all redeemed through Christ’s love. If we accept it. Would you like to pray with me and be saved?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: My parents used to take me to Bighorn Canyon every summer. There’s this place where you can stand on the edge and get a triple echo if you yell loud enough.

dialogues.speaker: EVANGELIST
dialogues.text: I don’t get it.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 33.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I would just yell my own name over and over, and eventually I could convince myself that someone was calling out to me.

dialogues.speaker: EVANGELIST
dialogues.text: Maybe you need to re-read this. She tries to hand Lamb the comic book again, but Lamb sei her wrist. Lamb’s eyes are shining, solemn.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You're wasting your life. I can already tell it’s too late for me to be normal. Maybe it’s not too late for you.

dialogues.speaker: EVANGELIST
dialogues.text: Let go of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb has been wandering for a while when she comes upon t enormous neon facade of the Imperial Palace. There’s a si advertising “LIVE DEALER-TAINERS! Only place in Vegas whe the dealers SING and DANCE!" Lamb shrugs, exhausted, and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: “Holly Jolly Christmas” Lamb enters the lobby of the hotel. The night is in full swing. She walks toward the main bar. The bartender, “SWEET” WILLIAM CARR, is in his mid thirti He would be handsome in the right scenario, but Vegas has taken its toll on him. His hair is a mess, his expression weary, and arms are patterned with tattoos of questionabl quality.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Excuse me, bartender? William seems annoyed by this formal mode of address.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes, drunkard?  Lamb scans the liquor selection and lands on a bright, cartoonish looking bottle.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’ll have the peach schnapps. William shudders visibly at this request.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Peach schnapps. Neat? Lamb blinks. WILLIAM (CONT’D) Would you like ice?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No thanks. Takes up too much room in the glass, and I want as much liquor as possible. At this point, William is humoring her.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Oh. I agree. 34. As he grabs a highball glass from behind the bar, he look Lamb’s T-shirt and reads it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (deadpan) “I Dice Las Vegas.”

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: It doesn’t really make sense, does it? William likes to spook young girls. He lunges across and stares her down accusingly.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It makes perfect sense if you’ve come to here chop people up into little pieces. Lamb doesn’t flinch.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Oh, great. ‘Cause that’s totally why I’m here. William slides the schnapps across to Lamb. the bar  35.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When do the “dealer-tainers” perform?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Let’s see, it’s almost nine...ah, yes. Looks like my dear friend Loray is on deck. He gestures to a YOUNG AFRICAN-AMERICAN WOMAN leaving a crowded blackjack table. Another DEALER is in the process subbing in at the table.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here we go. An EMCEE’s voice booms over the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the Imperial Palace is proud to present the musical stylings of our dealing diva, Loray! William mutters to himself as he wipes down the bar.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She hates the word “diva.” People at the bar turn toward Loray as she moves to the center of the room, holding a cordless mic. She has a commanding presence, even in her silly Imperial Palace uniform. The bar patrons begin to murmur and speculate as what Loray might sing.

dialogues.speaker: MALE PATRON
dialogues.text: Ooh. Look at this black girl! I bet she’s gonna blow the doors off. His friend’s response is equally stereotypical.

dialogues.speaker: PATRON
dialogues.text: Oh yeah man, she’s gonna take us to church!

dialogues.speaker: PATRON
dialogues.text: (calling out) Do Aretha! “Respect!” Loud, recorded music fills the casino. But it’s not the powerhouse R&B song everyone is expecting. Rather, it’s the gentlest, whitest ballad imaginable: “In Room,” by the Beach Boys,  36. Loray’s voice is pure and sweet.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: There's a world where I can go and tell my secrets to. In my room...

dialogues.speaker: PATRON
dialogues.text: BOOOOO! What is this? Patron #2 dismisses Loray with a pointed finger, jabbing wildly to the left as if to direct her offstage.

dialogues.speaker: PATRON
dialogues.text: To the left, girl! An elderly WHITE WOMAN turns to her companion.

dialogues.speaker: OLD WHITE WOMAN
dialogues.text: (disappointed) I thought she was going to have soul. William returns to Lamb’s corner of the bar, shaking his as the customers hiss and complain.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She’s not supposed to sing this. She’s been warned. Indeed, we see the PIT BOSS frowning at his defiant emplo

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: But it’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: People here don’t want beautiful. They want--

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK GIRL
dialogues.text: (screaming) Ke$ha!

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I don’t know what that is.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Now it's dark and I'm alone but I won't be afraid... Lamb watches Loray sing and is affected. There’s somethin brave about Loray’s sincerity and conviction in this room full of bawdy revelers.  37. William, despite his toughness, is touched by the fact th Lamb is touched.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I’m William.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Lamb. Lamb Mannerheim. She offers him her GLOVED HAND. He notices the compressio garment for the first time, but only hesitates for an ins before shaking her hand. Loray finishes her song on a high, clear note.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: In my room... Lamb takes her first sip of the drink and makes a horrifi face. A river of peach nastiness escapes down her chin. William hands her a cocktail napkin as tepid applause fil the casino.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Was that your first, ah, schnapp? Lamb’s voice is a faint croak.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: My first anything.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Here. This is called a “water back.” (winking) All the experienced drinkers order these. He gives Lamb a glass of water. She downs it gratefully. Lamb takes a PRESCRIPTION PILL BOTTLE out of her purse, shaking a few capsules into her hand. She puts the bottle down for a moment to politely applaud Loray. As Lamb turns away, William zeroes in on the label, readi it: VICODIN (HYDROCODONE). His eyes are filled with longi Desire. Pain. Lamb turns back and William acts casual. Loray is headed straight for the bar. She squeezes in next to Lamb.  38.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Well, the good news is, I’m off for the night. We are officially on LST: Loray Standard Time.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You were great, honey. In what may have been your final performance.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Yup, my ass is grass. Management says they want me to sing “Respect.” I mean, can you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (dry) No. Why would anyone want to hear a rousing Motown crowd-pleaser?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I loved your song. Loray barely glances at Lamb.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Brian Wilson. That’s my jam. I mean, I prefer his more obscure compositions, but...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Loray, this is my new friend Lamb Loray looks at Lamb then back at William. She rolls her e as if to say: you're hitting on this?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: I hope that’s Pedialyte, ‘cause your new friend is 10.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m 21. Loray glances at Lamb’s modest decolletage.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: 21 double-A. You're a fetus. She accepts a COCKTAIL that William has automatically pou for her; we can see this is a standard end-of-shift ritua

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Lamb is...what, celebrating her birthday? Where are your friends? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Surely there must be a gaggle of drunk college girls looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: A gaggle? No, I think a pride.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: A murder. Like crows.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: No, no, no, a flock! Get it? A flock of--

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Too obvious, honey.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m here in town alone, actually. Loray looks up from her drink and snorts.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Let me guess. You came here-- hm, best case scenario, you came here to be... (deciding) A showgirl.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Come on. You’re sitting here alone on a Monday night in December. Cute little face, calling yourself LAAAM-buh.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: That’s my real name.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Weave down to your butt...

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: This is my hair.  40.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Bleach blonde...

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Real blonde. I’m half Finnish. Loray tosses back most of her cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Hey, look. I’m half-finish, too. (to William) Top me off. She chuckles and heads toward the bathroom. William reach for Loray’s glass to refill it. Before he can stop Lamb, she’s jumped off the stool and i following Loray. Bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Don’t chase it into its cave. It bites. Lamb realizes she’s left her purse hanging on the chair. Naively, she continues on her way, calling back to Willia

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Watch my purse, please. Thanks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TOILET flushes. Loray emerges from the stall and sees L standing by the sinks, her eyes narrow and indignant.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Whoa. You look like an angry...baby...cobra. (beat) Look, I’m sorry I gave you shit back there. I have to amuse myself somehow.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m not a showgirl. Loray pumps soap into her hands, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: No one cares what you are. Lamb is overly invested in proving her innocence.  41.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I care very much. I care how I’m perceived. Besides, I could never do that even if I wanted to. (solemn) People would stare. I have a condition. A skin condition. She holds up her gloved hands. Loray, who is casually rin her hands in the sink, barely glances.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Yeah? I have a skin condition too. It’s called “black.” She laughs at Lamb’s angst.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (mocking) “People would stare.” Yeah. Try being me at the cell phone store.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Um... Loray walks up to the high-tech Dyson hand dryer, her dripping fingers outstretched.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Shh. This is the best part. She lowers her hands into the wind tunnel, then withdraws them slowly and indulgently.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Love the Airblade. She shakes her head, satisfied. As she heads for the door Lamb interrupts once more.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I'm from a conservative religious community where I wasn’t allowed to date or dance or even attend a normal school. Then I was in an accident that left a third of my body burned and disfigured. I don’t think there is a God anymore, which is a pretty big deal for me to be saying, because God used to be sorta my jam. Loray blinks.  42.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I left my home for the first time today because I feel like I’ve missed out on all of this and I want to experience worldly pleasures for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Wow. Am I in the first five minutes of pornography?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No, I--

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: That is quite the pitch, Lamb. I have heard some crazy stories from some broken folks here in the People’s Republic of Bad Choices, but that one? That one takes the whole hash brownie. (suspicious) Are you looking for money or something? Are you a junkie? I bet those gloves are covering some tracks... Lamb whips off her cardigan wordlessly. We see not Lamb, Loray, as she looks at Lamb’s scars.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: You're telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: And you're all by yourself, looking for trouble. You want to be a criminal?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No. No, not a criminal. I just want to be an American.  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loray is walking quickly across the casino floor. She’s changed into STREET CLOTHES and carries a backpack. Lamb trots after her eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: I don’t know yet. I know if I leave you by yourself, you’re going to wind up somewhere horrible, like the trunk of a car or Circus Circus. I feel an strange sense of responsibility toward you. You're just a little deep-fried pickle from Ohio...

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Montana. They're veering back toward the BAR, where William regard them with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: From Montana, population four, and you came here to commit sins. What did you have in mind, specifically?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Well, intoxicants, games of chance...

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Sex? (looking Lamb over) I’m sure you’ll have no problem finding someone to wreck that. Lamb is uncomfortable with this suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Um, well, just basically the whole Vegas experience. (then) Hey, thanks for watching my purse! They've arrived at the bar. Lamb takes her purse from William, who looks a bit guilty.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Thanks for believing in me. What’s going on?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 44,

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: I’m taking Lamb downtown.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: OMF-Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You should come with us!

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: William’s in the program. He only goes out for donuts and his “Higher Power.”

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I’m off at eleven. (to Loray) You have my number. The new number, the 702... Loray raises an eyebrow at him, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: I got your number all right, Pedo-Bear. Have a nice night.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Wait! This is to pay for my drink. She tosses a single bill onto the bar as Loray hustles he toward the casino exit.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Come on, Lamb..what’s your last name?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Mannerheim.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Jewish? Lamb gasps, delighted by this “shocking” suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No! They disappear out the casino doors.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Uh, sorry?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 45.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No, it’s cool! Did you really think I was Jewish? Wow! BACK ON WILLIAM: Watching their departing forms, William scoops the money off the bar. Like the cab driver, he’s surprised by the bill’s denomination. INT. LORAY’S CAR - NIGHT Lamb rides shotgun in Loray’s beat-up Hyundai. We hear a DIALOGUE SNIPPET from the Natural Born Killers soundtrack followed by the appropriate song.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Why are we leaving?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: If you want to see Las Vegas, we have to go to Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: But we’re in Las Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: No, we’re not. We’re in Paradise. Lamb is perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They may call this the “Vegas Strip,” but it’s actually located in a census-designated area called Paradise. Paradise, Nevada. You can look it up. Most tourists don’t know. They all say they’re headed to Vegas, but technically, they're going to Paradise. Lamb stares longingly out at the lights of the Strip.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I want to see Paradise, then.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: No you don’t, Lamb. Paradise is processed cheese. Do you want roller coasters and a fake Eiffel Tower and a bunch of tourists clapping for a frigging computerized fountain? Yay, robot! Yay, robot fountain! No. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want real Las Vegas, where the locals go. None of this trifling theme park trash. Actually, the other stuff sounded pretty good to Lamb.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: It’s just that I’ve never been to a theme park. Besides Creation Land.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: What is Creation Land?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: It’s a place in South Dakota with rides and um, exhibits about how humans were created by God and lived among the dinosaurs. Loray throws her head back and laughs heartily.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They have a pretty cool log ride...Oh, the Trop Light. This is the worst, huh? They're stuck at the infamous traffic light. Loray looks suspiciously at Lamb.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: “Trop Light.” How long have you been here? You’re sure you’re not a hooker?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: It bothers me so much when you say things like that.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Terrible. EXT. “REAL” LAS VEGAS - NIGHT Loray drives through downtown Vegas, aka “Glitter Gulch.” Everything seems dirtier, more tragic, and also much more romantic.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Glitter Gulch. This is the real life, yes indeed.  47. Lamb rolls down the window, then cautiously rolls it back halfway.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: This is where you go for fun?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Sure, when I’m not at school or at the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (surprised) You go to school?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Yeah, UNLV. Is that so shocking? You don’t have any black friends, do you? Everyone says they have the one black friend, but you don’t even know that guy.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: We had a visiting pastor from Africa all last summer.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: If he comes back next year, tell him Loray says hi. Lamb changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: What’s your major? Loray expertly maneuvers herself into a parking spot.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Filn.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Oh. There was nothing like that at my college. Lamb shakes her head as they climb out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Really? Nobody made shorts?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: We weren’t allowed to wear shorts.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of LOCAL HIPSTERS snakes around outside Loray’s favorite bar, The Sceptre. Loray and Lamb are quickly wav to the front of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Lamb’S GLOVED HAND, gripping an oversized LEVER.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All right, let’s get this out of the way. Pull. Reveal Lamb in the crowded bar, the kind of place that ha Christmas lights even when it isn’t Christmas. She eagerl yanks the lever on a campy vintage SLOT MACHINE. The machine’s display reveals a CHERRY, a BELL and “BAR.”

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There. You gambled. You played your game of chance. And now you see why it’s stupid. Let’s move. She tries to urge Lamb ahead, but Lamb is perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: What’s “bar”? Did I lose?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Yes, Lamb, you lost. Ultimately, everyone loses. If you lit that dollar on fire, at least you'd have kindling. I have no respect for gamblers. They make their way toward the bar.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You deal cards for a living.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: That's right, for a living. Not for my own personal edification. Charlie! Hey, Charlie! CHARLIE, a cute, tattooed FEMALE BARTENDER, looks up from taps, where she’s busily filling pints. She grins.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Loray-who-I-wanna-lay. What are we thinking?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 49.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: I’m thinking we're going to need some shots. Line ‘em up.

dialogues.speaker: BEGIN DRINKING SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Loray and Lamb are ensconced at their own tiny table near jukebox. Loray’s HIPSTER FRIENDS hover around them. They tight jeans, scarves, ironic T-shirts, weird beards, the whole nine. Loud music blasts. The mood is crowded, boozy festive. A tray of assorted shots sits in front of them. Loray dow one effortlessly; Lamb attempts a sip. Loray proudly plays show-and-tell with her new “discovery

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lamb’s from Montana. She was home- schooled. The hipsters shout over the jukebox, admiring Lamb.

dialogues.speaker: HIPSTER
dialogues.text: Wow! That’s awesome.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: It is?

dialogues.speaker: HIPSTER
dialogues.text: It’s anti-establishment. The public school system in this country a joke. I’m going to home-school my kids for sure.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Maybe don’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Lamb has never danced. She’s not on Facebook. She’s never even seen an R-rated movie.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I saw The Passion of the Christ.

dialogues.speaker: HIPSTER
dialogues.text: So basically, you’ve avoided so much empty, spirit-stealing pop culture. (beat) You're lucky.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 50.

dialogues.speaker: HIPSTER
dialogues.text: Right? It’s so punk rock.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Thanks?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Watch her try to drink this. Loray pushes a SWEET TART toward Lamb. Everyone watches L as if she’s an exotic zoo animal. Lamb takes a tentative of the vile pink concoction. Her face crumples.

dialogues.speaker: HIPSTER
dialogues.text: She can’t do it!

dialogues.speaker: HIPSTER
dialogues.text: Her face, like, repels the booze.

dialogues.speaker: HIPSTER
dialogues.text: Amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HIPSTER GIRL and her GAY HIPSTER FRIEND drape a trendy fringed SCARF over Lamb’s neck, tucking it fashionably.

dialogues.speaker: HIPSTER GIRL
dialogues.text: This is so cute on you. It’1ll cover up some of your battle damage.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I like it. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GAY HIPSTER FRIEND
dialogues.text: It’s a keffiyeh.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: HIPSTER GIRL
dialogues.text: A keffiyeh. It’s a Muslim head scarf. Lamb nearly does a SPIT TAKE.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (choked) Muslim?

dialogues.speaker: GAY HIPSTER FRIEND
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t worry; it’s not offensive to them or anything. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GAY HIPSTER FRIEND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These things are so popular; they're totally depoliticized.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Okay. The two of them admire their handiwork. The scarf does lo kind of adorable on Lamb.

dialogues.speaker: HIPSTER GIRL
dialogues.text: Phenomenal.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Why does everyone keep saying phenomenal? A scarf isn't a phenomenon of any kind.

dialogues.speaker: GAY HIPSTER FRIEND
dialogues.text: On you it is. You go, Baby Gisele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb and another GROUP OF HIPSTERS are on the postage-sta sized dance floor. Everyone BOPS AROUND to the Black Keys Lamb bends her knees awkwardly. She doesn’t know how to d and her skin grafts limit her movement.

dialogues.speaker: DANCING HIPSTER
dialogues.text: (to friend, pointing at Lamb ) She was in a plane crash.

dialogues.speaker: DANCING HIPSTER
dialogues.text: Like, a 747?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: It was a single-engine plane.

dialogues.speaker: DANCING HIPSTER
dialogues.text: You've had a crazy life, man. Loray dances over holding two cans of CHEAP DOMESTIC BEER She shouts over the loud music.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Look. You’re on a dance floor and hell hasn’t swallowed you up. Lamb looks around at the DANCING IDIOTS in skinny jeans.  52.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (dry) Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Ha. All right.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Hey, I just realized that we do have something in common.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: We do, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yes. You don’t have any black friends either.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Drink your beer. She hands Lamb a beer. Lamb looks at the CAN. The beer is called “Snowy Piste”; the can depicts a man skiing down a mountain.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: “Snowy Piste.”

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: It’s ironically delicious. (then) Oh, shit. Look who came out for the first time in MONTHS. She shouts toward the offending entrant. Lamb peeks up ov the bobbing heads.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sweet William. William nods at them as he passes the doorman and maneuve himself through the crowd. Lamb sees him and lights up. S waves. Loray seems sincerely shocked-- perhaps even a bit hurt-- by William’s arrival.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He never comes out. Never-ever-ever- ever-ever.... Lamb interrupts the drunken broken record.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Right, he doesn’t come out.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 53. William makes his way to dance floor. He looks good in hi non-bartender street clothes. Tough, but good.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: William, I thought you were going to pick up a second shift tonight.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I changed my mind, called Patti. (to Lamb) I thought Loray was going to look after you. She’s got you drinking “Snowy Piss?”

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I haven't had a sip. As it turns out, I’m hopeless at drinking. Loray grabs Lamb’s beer can and shotguns it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I could have told you that back at the hotel. I was there for the “schnapp-ocalypse.”

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m going to go get a cup of water or something. Smiling, she dashes off to the bar. Loray shimmies up nex William, dancing. He frowns at her as she does the Swim.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Lor? Show-and- tell?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Hey, she wanted to come here. William, she’s from, like, a religious commune. Okay? Like, Basement. Religious. Slave. She's never done any of this. It’s like she’s a weird-ass Disney princess that’s been locked in a tower her whole life. (singing The Little Mermaid) “She wants to be where the people are. She wants to see, wants to see them dancing...”

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Is that true?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 54. Loray is at the stage of tipsiness in which everything is hilarious. Paraphrasing Ariel:

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: (still singing) “She was-- what’s the word-- BURNED? When’s it her tuuurn?”

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I believe the sheltered bit. She’s definitely confused about certain customs. Do you know how much money she tipped me for one drink?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: She's country, huh? Did she put pennies on the bar?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Well, don’t complain, because I didn’t get a tip! She did not tip me, and I sang. From the heart! I was an unexpected treat. Before William can ask any more questions, Lamb returns f the bar with a soft drink.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Would you believe I got this for free? They said designated drivers get free pop.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: What largesse. Lamb leans against the wall. Though she’s trying to stay energetic, her body language betrays that she’s SORE and TIRED. She touches her arm. William notices.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Do you want to sit down?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m fine. (then) I don’t see any seats, anyway. The bar is indeed packed, sweaty and seat-less.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 55.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: There’s an upstairs bar. It’s sort of not open on weeknights, but they know me here. They don’t care. Maybe we'll just sit down for a few minutes. Lamb considers this cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you scared of me?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (yes) No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'd understand if you were.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Why, because you have a leather jacket and some tattoos? Big deal. I know ministers who look as “tough” as you. Punks for Jesus. Yeah, that’s old news.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (take aback) Well, those guys are faking it. They're using a look to sell religion.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: They're playing a part, same as you. I don’t know what you’re selling, but I suspect you're as toothless as they are.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You're mean, Lamb. I think I’11 just let you suffer.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: What? William would never, but he’s very convincing.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You can stand here throbbing in pain. I don’t care. Hey, there are some nice seats in the latrine if Hepatitis B is on your to-do list.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 56.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (emphatic) Take me upstairs, please. Everyone turns around, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William gently helps Lamb up the steep bar stairs. She’s having trouble.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Thanks. (embarrassed) I get really sore and stiff at night. I’m just-- I can’t move very well anymore.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Me neither, but I don’t have a cool, tragic excuse. I’ve got a hundred bucks that says you can dance better than I can. As William helps her, we see him discreetly RETURNING THE she left him, tucking it back into her purse. She doesn’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Dancing? No. All I can do is sort of bounce up and down.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: There’s nothing wrong with that. All dancing is just a prelude to bouncing anyway, right? He winks.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (tight-lipped) Mm-hm. Lamb’s not sure why she’s following this guy upstairs, bu it’s too late to turn back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William unhooks a rope blocking the entrance. The upstair bar is a quiet, empty room with an old-school big screen a Christmas tree, and plenty of seating. Lamb and William down at a high-top table.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 57. There’s a row of PAPER CHRISTMAS STOCKINGS tacked to the with EMPLOYEES’ names on them.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Oh, stockings for the people who work here. That must be so fun. William can’t help but smile at Lamb’s wistful enthusiasm everyday things.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t have anything to drink.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don’t drink.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Like me.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Not even a little. (then) I don’t drink anymore. I had some problems with, ah, substances, and the sale thereof. (beat) Did some time. In prison.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Oh. Lamb opens her purse, looking for something. She pulls ou the FLIER advertising “Ryder,” the prostitute. Her face f as she looks at the image.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I got this on the street. She shows him solemnly, as if it’s a rare, horrible artif

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah, you always see these on the Strip. Kind of grim, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I can’t stop thinking about her. I wish I could find her. She must be so scared, don’t you think?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 58.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ah, this isn’t even a real girl. These places use fake, misleading pictures. (then) I hear.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: The picture might be fake, and the name might be fake, but if you dial this number, a real human being shows up. William scans the flier.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She does in-call as well. That means you can also come to her...

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I’m worried about her. William, jaded, can’t believe how idealistic this girl is

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You can’t just go around saving people. Trying to do that here is like that arcade game, you know, with the little mallet? You put one devil down, another one’s just gonna pop up.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: My religion (catching herself) Well, I’m an atheist now, but my former religion says if you can save one soul, you can save the world. Lamb is rummaging in her purse. She takes out her VICODIN BOTTLE and opens it. She shakes out three pills. Shakes again. NOTHING LEFT.
