dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh no. Oh gosh.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What is it? Lamb is panicking.  59.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Some of my pills are missing. I need these.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No worries. You probably have, like, unlimited refills right?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Somebody stole from me. They stole medication from a burn survivor. (then) Do you think Loray would take it? William’s guilt is suddenly compounded.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No. Loray wouldn’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I don’t know her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh. No. She’s so good, Lamb. She’s a deeply good person. She loves the Beach Boys. (serious) I’ve worked with her for four years; she’s like my sister. She’s my pit wife. Please don’t even think for a second it was Loray. You have enough for now, right? There’s a bunch of 24-hour pharmacies right around here. I'll drive you.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Okay. The mood has changed. Lamb swallows one of her remaining Vicodins as William looks around for something, anything, cheer her up. He glances at the big TV.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hey, you wanna see if there’s a silly movie on or something?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (dejected) Sure.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loray is grinding with a HEAVILY BEARDED GUY. She takes a swig of beer and tries unsuccessfully to make out with hi through his mass of facial hair.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: I can’t find your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William takes a remote from behind the bar and turns on t big TV. He flips through the channels and finds... The classic 1960s special, Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer Lamb reacts like a delighted child.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer! I remember this. William watches with her, equally pleased. The light flic on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Of course. Total classic. Even I’ve seen this and my childhood was a blur of beatings and evictions.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I watched this like, every year when I was little. Then my parents realized it left the Christ out of Christmas, and that was the end of that. They watch for a moment. It’s the “Island of Misfit Toys” sequence, in which a haunting song is sung by imperfect t a polka-dotted elephant, a boat that doesn’t float, a tra with square wheels, and a lonely little rag doll (among others).

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, this part is so sad. These are the Misfit Toys. Nobody wants them because they’re defective.

dialogues.speaker: ELEPHANT
dialogues.text: (on TV) How'd you like to be a spotted elephant?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 61.

dialogues.speaker: BOAT
dialogues.text: (onscreen) Or a boat that can't float? Lamb watches, her eyes shining. Then:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with the doll?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Nobody wants her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Seriously, though, what’s her defect? I can see the train has square wheels. And the elephant has polka-dots. But that little doll looks completely normal. What’s she doing with those broken toys? We see the rag doll. She does look perfectly normal. (Thi one thing that has never made sense about the “Misfit Toy scene.)

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: We probably just can’t see what’s wrong with her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You think it’s under her dress or something? Lamb is uncomfortable. Her voice is strained.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Or...maybe she’s perfect.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Maybe she’s just in the wrong place. Loray emerges from the stairwell, interrupting them. She glances at the TV, drunk and dismissive.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: What is this? Gumby?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 62. William and Lamb groan at Loray’s flippancy toward such a beloved show.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You don’t know what this is?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: You guys need to come downstairs immediately. Some people are line dancing as a joke. William fakes jumping out of his seat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She needs to rest.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No, I’m fine now. Much better. They rise and head toward the stairwell. Loray continues babbling happily.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Hey William, you know that girl who always does the splits? She did it again. I'm like, bitch, we get it, you can put your whole vagina on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna fight her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I think it’s time to switch to water. Loray takes a last glance at the TV and shakes her head a they descend. She loudly whispers to William.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You take a girl upstairs and you put on cartoons? You’re a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb, William and Loray walk down Fremont Street, eating DOGS from a busy food truck.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 63.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: So is dirty street meat against your religion? Lamb is enjoying her hot dog immensely.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I think it could be my religion. CHARLIE, the CUTE GIRL BARTENDER suddenly rushes up to La still wearing her bar apron.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (breathless) Hey, thank you so much for that tip. Wow. I just wanted to say thanks before you take off. I really appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I can go to Burning Man now!

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Great. Charlie, grinning, runs back into the bar. William realiz Lamb has left another massive tip, but shrugs it off as typical weirdness.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: What was that all about?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m really not sure. A beat as they walk. William changes the subject, ticking Lamb's “crimes” off on his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: So. You gambled, you drank, you danced with-- what did you call them, Sodomites?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yes. I failed at all three tasks.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You watched a movie with Santa Claus. (redneck drawl) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're wearin’ anti-Amurrican clothing. He flicks at the fringe on Lamb's scarf.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you going to do next?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: She needs to get turned out.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Hm? William shoots an annoyed look at Loray.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: What? Don’t tell me “sins of the flesh” aren’t part of the agenda. It should be right there in your little Sanrio day planner: GET LAID. What else is there? At least you have to do something dirty.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (flustered) Okay. Well. Okay then. Let’s go...see...Goddess.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: What's Goddess? Lamb is already blushing before she even describes it.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You know. The adults-only show? With the topless girls and the volcanoes? (sighing) You know, where Nomi performs in Showgirls? I know the Stardust isn’t there anymore, but maybe they moved the show to a different venue. Loray bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Lamb, Showgirls is not real. Okay? It is not a documentary about Las Vegas. It is fiction. It came out of a horny Dutch man’s imagination.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 65.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I know! I just thought maybe Goddess was real. The character of Nomi, she makes such a big deal about being in it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: That’s perfectly understandable. I thought it was real myself.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: (dying) William, you did not.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I did. I’ve looked for it. Checked every marquee.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: All right, I’m an idiot. I'ma gullible idiot from the prairie. Where do we go next, then?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Back to Paradise, baby!

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I thought we hated Paradise. I thought Paradise was processed cheese and dumb fountains, etcetera.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: After hours is when the employees come out to play.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: We know everyone, and everyone loves us. We can go wherever we want and our money is no good.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Um, I sort of need to find a pharmacy first. I take medication. For my pain. And somebody stole most of it. Loray glances at William. A COLD, DISAPPOINTED GLANCE, bu brief enough that Lamb doesn’t notice. Lamb turns to Lora

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think it could be one of your friends?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 66.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: (sadly) Possibly.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I’ll take you, Lamb. Loray, come on. I don’t want you driving.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: It’s fine. I’1l get a cab. (accusingly) You take her to the drug store, William. I’1l catch you later. She begins to walk away from them rather suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I need some breathing room. It’s like shawarma and liquor are having a UFC fight in my stomach. I’1ll see you guys on the Strip.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Okay. Lamb, high on life and being “cool”, flashes the peace si

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Later! Peace out. Loray rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William waits behind the wheel of his TOYOTA. Lamb runs o of the 24-hour Walgreens clutching a PAPER BAG from the pharmacy. She slides into the front seat cheerfully.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Phew. That wasn’t so hard. They had it right there in the computer. He watches her gobble down a couple of pills with a bit t much enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Good, great. (then) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 67.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, can I ask you a sensitive question?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You know that prescription pain killers are extremely addictive, right?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I have very serious injuries.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No. I know. I know. I’m just saying that this is, sadly, my area of expertise. I happen to know that certain controlled substances, such as this one, can cause a dependency. Even when people don’t set out to abuse them. Lamb is crumpling the bag irritably.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I know all this. I spent six months in a hospital. I’m not some pill- abusing druggie criminal like the people you might know from “the joint.”

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Lamb. She sees how serious he is.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not something a person can always help. Even if they’re the most well-meaning, most responsible, nicest, loveliest person in the world and they’re named after a baby farm animal. Lamb looks away.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know people who’ve been so hooked on that stuff that they’d do anything to get it. Gross things. Really bad things, not fake-fun-bad like what you’re doing here.  68.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Look, I know you guys think what I’m doing here is so funny, but you have no idea how serious it is to me. Being here tonight goes against every belief that’s been instilled in me. It’s like bending a bone backwards. I’m trying to smile and have fun and let go, but I feel like I’m going to snap.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: If it makes you feel better, it’s not just you. Everyone who comes to Vegas is testing the tensile strength of their conscience.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Well, when does it get fun? I just want to have fun. How is this something people enjoy? Bars aren't fun. That bar smelled like the flu. And that dumb slot machine wasn’t fun. It took my money and just said “bar.” Great, I just paid ten dollars for a machine to tell me where I am. It’s not fun, William. I just want to do something that’s fun for me. William considers what might be fun for Lamb.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge ROLLER COASTER looms over the Strip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb, William and Loray wait in line for the roller coast Loray’s arms are crossed and she’s pissed off. Lamb, howe looks THRILLED.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Now this is wild and crazy, you guys!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (humoring her) I know.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 69.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: They didn’t have a roller coaster at Creation Land. I’ve never been on one. Aren’t you guys excited?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Loray, I think you might be Type D.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: What the hell is Type D?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You don’t know? It means depressed.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s just late on a Monday and I’m tired of being your magical negro.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh, boy.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: The “magical negro” is, uh, a narrative convention in which a black person uses their special black wisdom to help a dumb white person. We learned all about it in film school. Ghost, Green Mile, Bagger Vance. All magical negroes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Except you're not wise or magical. Loray burps.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Yes I am! Lamb, don’t I say a lot of things that make you go, “Wow, Loray just told me! She’s so insightful.”

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: That's extremely racist.  70.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (to Loray) Let’s face it. You’re no Bagger Vance.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Bagger Vance is immortal. He doesn’t age.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: No, that’s just what Will Smith looks like.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, the character didn’t age.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: What was the right answer? What was I supposed to say. William tries to put a friendly arm around Loray, but she shrugs him off, annoyed. Now we can see she’s REALLY MAD, not about the Bagger Vance thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William, Lamb and Loray stand behind the automated airgat as the COASTER TRAIN arrives in the station.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Look, Lamb. There’s a spot open at the front. Take it. Lamb hesitates, peering at the front car.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: But then I have to sit next to a strange man in a cowboy outfit.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: This is your first ride. You gotta have the front so you can feel the bugs hit your teeth. Lamb looks again at her fellow passenger.  71.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: The cowboy outfit has no...behind part.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Aw. Baby’s first assless chaps. Don’t worry. You don’t have to talk to him. Git. Lamb boldly jogs to the front of the coaster train. The airgates open. Loray is stuck riding with William. She lo away as they climb into the train and pull down the restraints.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Why are you mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: You know why. The roller coaster lurches out of the station.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Don’t be like this.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: It’s bad enough that you stole pain relief from a girl who’s held together with bandages and chewing gum. But it’s even worse that you're up her ass all night. The whole “white knight” routine you do. Helping her up that dark stairwell. Bringing her here-- you know we’re never caught dead doing this tacky shit! And you’re flirting with her. Making her feel pretty. It’s cruel.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She is pretty.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Obviously, yes, but she’s pretty like the Playboy Mansion. Looks like a dream, but you don’t want to pull up the carpet. The coaster ascends the lift hill.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why are you here?  72.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (defensive) I don’t know, I felt like it tonight. My sponsor says I can’t stay in forever and I thought it was time.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Time. I bet it’s time. You’re here because you found a blonde virgin with a purse full of dope.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Lor, I have not broken any promises. I’ve been staying out of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: “Trouble” is up there next to the naked cowboy, and you’re acting like you'd rather get in it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I know this is hard to believe, coming from me. But I would never take advantage of her.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Ha. Yes, it is hard to believe coming from you. The man they call “William the Conqueror.” “Fill’em Will’em.” “Bill the Butcher”...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Loray, I would never. Not her. I wouldn’t take that from her.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Didn't you already take something from her? A moment of silence. Loray looks off toward the side of t lift hill. They’re almost 200 feet above the Strip. William reaches for Loray’s hand. She’s confused for a moment. When William lets go, Loray opens her palm. He’s surreptitiously handed her FOURTEEN VICODIN PILLS.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: They're all there. I didn’t take a single one. I mean, yes, I took them out of her purse about four minutes after I met her. But I didn’t take them. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve thought about them nonstop since they’ve come into my possession, but I haven’t taken one. There’s a moment of relieved silence for Loray. Then:

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: What do you expect me to do with these? You know I prefer crack.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don’t know. We'll give them back to her and she’1l hate me and I’1l1 have a pathetic story for my next NA meeting.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: No. I like how she looks at you. She looks at you like you’re a good person and not a total jagoff.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I know. But I can’t let her think you stole it.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: I don’t care. Let’s protect her from something. She’s gotta hang on to some of that sweetness. As the train crests the lift hill, Loray tosses the handf of tiny white pills over the side.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Loray does her best meterologist impression.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Tonight’s Clark County forecast calls for scattered flurries. William watches the pills disappear.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, assholes.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Open your damn mouths! The train PLUNGES into the roller coaster’s spaghetti-lik mass of steel track.  74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb's head is hanging between her knees.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey. You going to be okay? They're standing on the still-busy sidewalk. Lamb downpla her nausea and discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m phenomenal. She stands up. We see a spot of BLOOD on the elbow of her cardigan.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: You're bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (downplaying) I think I bumped my elbow going around one of those turns. William pulls up the sleeve of the cardigan. Lamb recoils from this violation of privacy.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop it. The elbow of Lamb’s compression garment is SOAKED in bloo Loray winces and looks away.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You're hurt.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: It’s my skin graft. William is trying to stay calm.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Can they re-graft it? Lamb pulls away from him angrily.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yeah, at a special clinic in Minnesota for human-jerky. I TOLD you I was a mess. I told you. Nobody ever believes me.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You're not a mess. It’s not a big deal. You just need to take it easy. Chill at the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Chill? I’m tired of “taking it easy.” I’ve been taking it easy for two years now and I feel like I’m rotting alive.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: From a scientific standpoint, we’re all rotting alive.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: My gosh, I never thought about it that way. You’re so wise. On Loray: OWNED.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I think you’ve had enough fun for the night. We need to patch you up. Lamb is clutching her bleeding elbow.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Enough fun my skinless ass! It’s easy for you to say “enough” and to “take it easy”, because you already got to do everything you wanted. You already got to screw up and disappoint your whole family. On William: sadly, this is true.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've got those lines on your face and that silver in your hair because you lived. Now it’s my turn.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm a dirtbag. You don’t want to be like me.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (through tears) Yes I do.  76.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: You're lucky you had a nice life. I know you resent all the Jesus stuff and not being allowed to wear shorts and the fact that they made you practice the recorder every day.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: The flute.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: But there are worse things than being protected. Having someone care where you go and what happens to you. We can see that Loray has wished for this very thing. Wil glances at her protectively.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People in your family are probably looking for you right now. Nobody's looked for me in years. The last time someone Googled me, there was no Google. They had to Alta Vista that shit. Lamb looks up at Loray, still holding her elbow.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Also, I’m not the one bleeding on the street right now. You've lived, all right? All right, plane crash? You lived, you died, and now you’re living again. You’re a lot harder than most of these clowns. She gestures to the LATE NIGHT REVELERS on the street.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Let’s get you to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Don’t bother. They’1l just wrap it in some gauze and parade me around in front of the med students. I hate when people treat me like I’m some kind of curiosity. Loray glances at William. Guilty.  77.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just going to go back to my hotel.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You're not going alone.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Why not? I took a taxi from the airport. I know what I’m doing.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Let William take you back. William looks at Loray, surprised. Loray nods.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s the best guy when you need taking care of. Once I got food poisoning at work and he guarded the door to the women’s bathroom for six hours. William smiles at this awful-yet-touching memory.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s not perfect. I’1l tell you no lies. But he’1ll get you home in one piece. Or whatever pieces you've got left. Lamb giggles through the pain.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can trust him. With that, she extends her blessing. William’s gratitude evident. Loray’s RESPECT means a lot to him. Lamb considers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William flags a CAB. Loray waits with Lamb on the sidewal taxi appears and pulls up to the curb. William gives Loray a friendly hug and a peck.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (to Loray) Good night, sweetie.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 78.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: See you in the pit. William gestures for Lamb to enter the cab. She hesitates

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You go ahead. I want to say goodbye to Loray. William shrugs and hops in, leaving Loray and Lamb on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was truly a pleasure to meet you. I know our time together was short, but I valued it.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: It was something meeting you, too. (then) Hey, look, I’m sorry I teased you about all that sex stuff. I could tell it upset you. It was pretty insensitive of me.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Oh, sheesh, it’s fine. It’s not like I’m a virgin.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Uh, what? Lamb is shockingly casual.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’ve had sex. Of course. (explaining) I had sexual relations with Pastor Rick, or just “Rick” as he asked me to call him during that fateful youth retreat. I’d been attracted to him for a while and I succumbed to baser urges. Looking back, I can see that it was an abuse of power on his part, but what’s done is done... Loray’s like what the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me you’re surprised. You think fundamentalist Christians don’t have sex? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ha, everyone has sex. It’s the one thing they haven’t figured out how to control.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: I just thought...

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Even the church leaders do it. Sometimes they get caught with other men, even! Don’t you read the news? She hops into the cab, shrugging cheerfully despite her injury. Loray prevents her from shutting the car door.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Wait. What’s going to happen to you?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Let’s pretend I do.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Well, I know you think Las Vegas was kind of a bust. But this is all make-believe. It’s fake, like Goddess. Lamb smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you still want to be a regular American, like you said? Lamb nods.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think you need to go see America. Lamb takes in this advice. Then:

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Hey, you know how you said no one ever came looking for you? That nobody cares where you are?  80.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Well, I followed you into the bathroom. And then I followed you downtown and, well, I gotta say... more people should come looking for you. They’d find some amazing things. Lamb reaches, painfully, to shut the CAB DOOR. Loray intercepts, closing it gently and waving goodbye to her “Disney princess.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and Lamb enter the lobby. William is holding Lamb injured elbow. They look cozy. Yet another group of adorable young COLLEGE GIRLS walks b They're not “bad girls” ; they’re just having the time of their life. They carry drinks and laugh. Lamb watches the enviously. This is the normal life she dreams of. Three of them cluster together for a photo while one hold her camera phone.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL WITH CAMERA
dialogues.text: Say it with me, guys...1-2-3... (everyone together) Phenom-enal! Lamb turns to William suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Where do you think they’re going? William is dismissive. Derisive, even.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don’t know. There’s a nightclub at this hotel that all the “Trixies” and “Chads” seem to love. They're probably going there.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I want to go to the club.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s one of the recommended steps in wound care.  81.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Just for a minute. Just for one minute so I can see.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It’s not you. It’s loud and crowded and it’s full of disgusting aggressive people who will try to put their...private parts...against your...rear end.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You don’t have to mince words around me, William. You can say butt. Look, I said “butt” and hell didn’t swallow me up. A crying BRIDE stomps past, holding up her soiled hem.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (surprised) Okay? Okay! She clutches her elbow in pain, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long line of CLUBGOERS snakes out of a huge, high-conce Vegas hotel nightclub. William moves easily to the front of the line, exchanges pleasantries with the DOOR GUY, and ushers Lamb in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior of the club is a dark labyrinth. There are beautiful half-naked GIRLS dancing everywhere in Eden-the fig leaf ensembles. The music is bone-jarringly loud. Lamb keeps one hand on William’s shoulder as he cuts thro the crowd. She’s never seen this many people crammed into place.  82. They finally emerge at the CENTER OF THE CLUB. It’s the t of night when drunk and drugged people completely lose th minds. It’s so loud that William can’t speak to Lamb, and vice versa. He simply gestures as if to say, “Here we are Lamb's expression is hard to read. Her face is solemn. Th are CLUB KIDS going wild all around them. Lamb is surroun by mayhem and indecency. William is concerned. Has he gon too far? A TINSEL CANNON goes off, spewing silver tinsel into the It pours down on the cheering crowd. Lamb can’t move, but she smiles. She starts laughing. It’ the happiest William has seen her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb and William are standing in the corner of an OPEN ELEVATOR, about to ride up to her floor. Lamb’s hair is f of tinsel. Suddenly, two of the FRAT GUYS we saw when Lamb first arr run to make the elevator. One shoves his hand between the closing doors; they both hop in. Their eyes are bloodshot they're clearly messed up on some kind of disco biscuits.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Hi, guys! The two GUYS freeze, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Oh shit, it’s the narc. It’s the narc, man!

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No, silly, narcs report to me. I’m a fed, remember? The guys back away.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is my partner, Officer Cha. William plays along flawlessly.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Good evening, boys. Or should I say, good morning! My, you seem wide awake at such a wee hour.  83.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: (twitching) We drank a lot of coffee. Energy drinks.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Energy drinks.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Your pupils are unusually large. I better get my eye flashlight. The frat guys are wildly stabbing the “open door” button.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Very strange indeed, Officer Krupke. Say, do you mind if I ask where you purchased those drinks?

dialogues.speaker: FRAT GUY
dialogues.text: We have to go. The two guys dash off the elevator. William looks at Lamb amused.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: How long have you been here?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Only a few hours, I swear. INT. HOTEL ROOM - 3:00 A.M. Lamb and William enter Lamb’s suite. William is surprised its size.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: This is some room. Did they comp you or something?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I had a coupon. This seems an unlikely explanation, but William lets it g

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was planning to stay here for a while anyway. William looks around the immaculate suite. He sees Lamb's clothing. Her Obama book. Her flute in its case. Then he Lamb's DISHES sitting in a neat stack.  84.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What’s with the dishes? Lamb sighs.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I brought my own dishes from home. I don’t know why people find this so strange! (exasperated) I had to let go of a lot of prejudices and fears to come to Las Vegas, so I don’t know why it’s such a big deal that I’d want to have my own tableware. I should have something familiar. Hotels are notoriously dirty.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It’s fine. I was just wondering. You know, hotel comforters are supposed to be the worst. Lamb eyes the patterned BEDSPREAD warily.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, they don’t wash them and they’re allegedly covered in se... (correcting himself) Cigar...ette ash.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Should I take it off?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Sure. Lamb pulls the comforter off the bed and onto the floor. There’s something awkward about discussing the bed.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You didn’t have to come all the way to my room. I could have found my way up from the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I see that you can take care of yourself. You’d already used some kind of mind trick on those bros in the elevator.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 85.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Well, that’s a bit like hypnotizing chickens. (off his blank look) Easy. William sits down on the DESK CHAIR.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: So when you said you'd be staying here for a while, how long did you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I just don’t want to go back to Billings.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: There are other places on the good- times continuum between Billings and the Vegas Strip.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I'm figuring that out.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hm. You know, I think you'd love Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Chicago. Lamb smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Since I’m never going to see you again, you should know-- you have a right to know-- that I’m the one who stole your Vicodin. I fished them right out of your bag.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Abhh... We think she’s going to protest.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--bviously.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: How did you know that?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 86.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I left my purse with you and you're a recovering drug addict. My mom always says that when people tell you who they are, you should listen. William nods: fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, I understand. I’m not without my vices. I’m totally addicted to-- well, you know those vanilla sandwich cookies, with the creme filling? I love them. If you had a big bag of those cookies, boy, when you weren’t looking? I'd eat a couple. Maybe I’d eat 10. My flesh is weak. She’s anything but weak, and William knows that.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No, I’1l admit it. I love vanilla sandwich cookies. (quietly, almost whispering) And also Vicodin.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What? Lamb whispers again, this time closer to him. He nods. WILLIAM (CONT’D) I think you can get the situation under control. The cookies, I mean. Lamb looks worried and self-conscious. Obviously, he’s no talking about the cookies.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: If you need help, there are lots of counselors that specialize in creme- filled desserts. No big whoop. But personally? I think there probably isn’t anything you can’t do.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 87.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: William, I mean no offense. But are you trying to get into my surgical support hose?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No. This is not to say I wouldn't. I would. Lamb blushes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would! I love support hose. I would peel ‘em right off. Throw them around my head like a lasso. Lamb bursts out laughing despite being totally scandalize

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think I should go. I understand if you don’t want to exchange email or whatever. Or regular addresses. You do live on a street, right?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Rural Route 13. And don’t go.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (surprised) What?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Don't go.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I lied to you. I’m a liar and an addict Just another Vegas lost cause. Why do you keep trusting me?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: It’s a very potent act to put your faith in someone who’s lost their faith in themselves.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess it is. Lamb seems to have an epiphany.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Will you help me with something that might seem weird?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 88.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What have we been doing all night? INT. HOTEL ROOM - 3:30 A.M. Lamb sits on her bed and picks up the ROOM PHONE. We can’ see who she’s calling. William lingers supportively.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi. I have a question. My name is Lamb. (calmly) No, actually I am not a prostitute. EXT. CHEETAH STRIP CLUB - 4:00 A.M. Dusk approaches. Lamb, still in her bloodied cardigan and jeans, approaches the cheesy, neo-Classical facade of the CHEETAH GENTLEMAN'S CLUB. William is apprehensive about t plan.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I’m going in with you, of course.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Certainly not. I have to go alone.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What? I’m coming in!

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Why? Is this a religious thing? You don’t trust me, do you? I don’t blame you if you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I trust you! It’s just that I will die of embarrassment if I have to enter this temple of Jezebel with a guy that I like!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh. (pleased) Oh.  89. Lamb walks toward the club. She offers the COVER CHARGE t one of the two BOUNCERS. He waves her in wordlessly. She looks small and vulnerable as she ducks through the doorw

dialogues.speaker: BOUNCER
dialogues.text: I gotta call my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb enters. The vibe at a strip club at 4:00 AM is a str one. Some of the GIRLS are cashing out. There are girls onstage, girls leaving. Lamb scans the room. A baby-faced, Michael Cera-esque MANAGER approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Hi, do you need an application? A STRIPPER in a dowdy PUFFER COAT, Uggs and a Chicago Bea hat heads for the door, counting a wad of bills.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Justice? What did I say about no street clothes on the work floor?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTICE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Bernard. She saunters out of the club, rolling her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: It really ruins the illusion. Thanks. (to Lamb) Sorry. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m looking for someone. The manager sighs.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Are you hear to make trouble? Collect a real or imagined debt? Choke a bitch out? Lamb reaches into her purse and slips a BILL into the manager’s hand. She shakes it firmly.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Peace be with you.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 90.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Oh. Merry Christmas. (looking at the bill) Please enjoy the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb crosses the club floor. It’s a sad place that masks sadness with colorful lights and thumping music. Lamb looks at one of the dancers and realizes: it’s STRIP #3 from the airport baggage claim. The girl meets Lamb’s gaze; she recognizes her, vaguely, but is too fucked up o something or other to register much. Lamb waves and continues across the floor. She follows tw GIRLS up a STAIRWAY and through an open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb cautiously enters the large, grimy DRESSING ROOM. Sh brightens immediately. She’s found the person she was loo for: A tired BRUNETTE in her mid-thirties, checking her makeup in the mirror. She wears a Santa Claus bikini.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Hello. Are you Ryder? “Ryder” has to think about that one.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Huh? Uh, yeah. Yeah, I’m Ryder. What do you want? She looks around as if expecting some kind of ambush. Lam holds up a familiar, crumpled yellow paper.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I called the number on the flier. Ryder takes a plastic BRUSH out of her purse and begins brushing the matted ends of her hair extensions.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: I’m not working tonight. Lamb begins picking soiled COSTUMES and DRESSES up off th floor. She brushes them off and starts hanging them neatl a nearby rack.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 91.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I know. The agency told me. I asked where I could find you, and they said you dance here.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: They're not supposed to give out that information. Lamb folds a bikini bottom and sets it on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I know. I’m afraid I lied. I told them I was your babysitter and there was an emergency. Ryder bristles, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: How do you know about my kids?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Did a guy put you up to this or something? I can do couples, but it costs extra.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Oh no, it’s just me. Lamb picks up a can of DISINFECTANT and sprays it liberal all over the room.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Why are you cleaning?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I just like things to be nice. Ryder is straddling the nasty old “boudoir” chair in her thin bikini bottoms.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: I get it. I’m weird about germs too. (Somehow, we doubt this.) A prolonged silence. Then:  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 92.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m supposed to be in the Jell-o pit in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I'd like to pay you for your time. Is there somewhere we can speak privately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb and Ryder soak their feet in a nasty old Jacuzzi in strip club dressing room. Lamb’s SUPPORT HOSE are off. Th water bubbles around their ankles.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: So this is nice!

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: (not really) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Okay, here's the thing: I’ma Christian. And a big part of that, at least ideally, is reaching out to people. Where there is charity, there is God. Ryder has been proselytized at before.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Oh no. No offense, but I hate all that religious stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Wait. Listen, I know what it’s like to not believe in anything. You see my scars?

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Yeah. No offense, that’s busted.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I was in a plane that went down. The boy who was courting me-- my boyfriend, I guess you would call him-- he was a pilot in the Air Force. It was our first date without a chaperone, and he decided to take me up. He was very experienced, but...  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 93.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Did he get as messed up as you? Lamb smiles. The Jacuzzi shuts off and the water stagnate

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: He got lucky.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Not a scratch, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No, he died. This matter-of-fact statement reveals how truly difficult Lamb’s recovery has been.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Hard to believe in God after that.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You said it, Ryder! That’s been my whole crisis. My cross to bear if you'll pardon the expression. I know you don’t like “religious stuff.”

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: S'fine.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: But if that hadn’t happened- the pain, the operations, the skin grafts, everything-- I wouldn’t have been able to come here. I wouldn’t have come to this incredibly spiritual city. I wouldn't have made new friends that I couldn’t have found anywhere else in the world. I wouldn’t have met William...

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: (interrupting) You think Vegas is spiri-chall?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Technically, this is Paradise.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Whatever. You hooked up with some guy and now you believe in God again? Girl, you’re just dickmatized.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 94,

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No. I know it seems strange to suffer so much pain for just the tiniest flash of beauty-- but it’s fair. I don’t know how, but it adds up. The world is tipped in favor of goodness. That’s how I know someone is there. I can’t see him, or her, or it, but I know. I can feel His hand on the scale, making things even out. Giving our lives worth. Ryder makes a face that (somewhat) approximates a SMILE.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: My time is almost up. Lamb stands up, wincing a little. The usual morning pain. walks over to her purse and takes out a MASSIVE ROLL OF BILLS.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t hand it to me. Just leave it on the side of the tub. Ryder looks at Lamb and realizes that she’s peeling off MULTIPLE HUNDRED DOLLAR BILLS.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, I said a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m giving you five grand in cash, and writing you a much bigger check as well. I know you guys don’t take checks, but I promise I’m good for it.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Is this a joke? Lamb is writing a CHECK with a pink ballpoint pen. She doesn’t even look up as she explains herself.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: There was a problem with the plane. Major mechanical failure. Our families-- my family and Micah’s family-- they sued and won. I’m worth like, eight million? She places the check and the cash on the side of the Jacu tub, as if it doesn’t matter if it falls in or gets soggy  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy)

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think people expected me to give it to my church, but I have some other ideas. Maybe I’1l be like... a traveling ministry. People are always saying “Oh, if I had millions of dollars, I would help people.” Well now, I’m that person.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Is this a reality show?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Then why?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Sometimes a little ripple can affect a big change, like... She quickly amends Melanie’s favorite saying, glancing at hot tub.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like, uh, like that jet in the tub. Just shooting out a little air. Ryder looks confused. Then:

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: It’s a good thing you picked me. Because these other girls-- man! some of them would just blow it all on junk or clothes or whatever. Not me. (rambling) I’m going to get some things for my boys. My one son’s birthday is the day after Christmas, so. She gathers up the money.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: That must have been a great present.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Why did you pick me, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I got the flier. I saw your picture. I liked your face.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 96. Ryder sees the HUGE FIGURE on the check and gasps in disbelief. She looks up at Lamb like “Are you serious?”

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: That picture’s 10 years old. I don’t even look like that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: But it’s still you. Don’t say that. (fierce) It’s still you. Lamb suddenly lunges forward and HUGS Ryder, who resists, arms and legs locked. Ryder has forgotten how to hug. But lets Lamb do it anyway. Passively, charitably, she allows hug. Lamb exhales, shuddering, into Ryder’s sun-damaged bosom. eyes are shut tight.

dialogues.speaker: RYDER
dialogues.text: You're giving me one thing to not screw up.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: As long as you try. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lamb heads down the staircase adjacent to the main sta she pauses. She reaches into her purse and tosses a handf of CASH into the air. It drifts gracefully down onto the floor. The STRIPPERS FREAK OUT.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE STRIPPER
dialogues.text: Holy crap!

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT STRIPPER
dialogues.text: These are Benjamins!

dialogues.speaker: CHUBBY STRIPPER
dialogues.text: Bloody Elbow’s making it rain!

dialogues.speaker: CRAWLING STRIPPER
dialogues.text: (pocketing bills) Thank you, Jesus. She crosses herself and prays quietly. Lamb watches for a beat. Then she hurries out the door of the club.  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is growing light. Lamb walks across the mostly em parking lot toward William. One of the bouncers calls out her, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: BOUNCER
dialogues.text: Hey, where you going? Lamb turns to face him, stumbling backwards. She opens he arms to embrace the world.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Everywhere. William takes her gloved hand. They walk off into the daw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a grey early morning. Williams HANDS are COVERING La EYES. He removes them, revealing... The Excalibur CASTLE that captured Lamb’s imagination whe she first arrived.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (pleased) The castle! Finally.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Do you like buffets? Lamb briefly recalls her bad buffet encounter. Then:

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I love them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb sits on the roof, watching the sun rise among the fa castle turrets. William appears with two plates. Lamb’s h MICKEY MOUSE PANCAKES, which she notices with delight. William settles in and takes in the sunrise. Lamb leans i suddenly and KISSES HIM. William is startled, but he does not resist.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 98.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes, I’ve done so much for you.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about the bar, when I said you weren’t scary. I lied. I’m terrified. Here, feel this. She puts his hand near her heart.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: That’s not fear.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You don’t think?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: It’s been a couple of years since my heart raced for any good reason.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Now it’s your turn. They KISS again. And we LEAVE them, looking out onto the waking city...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb returns to her hotel room alone, looking dreamy. Smiling, she packs her suitcase again, tossing everything with uncharacteristic recklessness. Before she exits, she takes one last look at the now sun- filled room. She rises onto her tiptoes and sinks. Up and down. Up and down again. It’s a strange little bounce. Her arms swing. Could it be? Lamb is...DANCING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb approaches the reservation desk, her bags in tow.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Checking out?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Yes. 1427.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 99. She slides over her key. The clerk types on the computer. demeanor changes to one of recognition/annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: 1427. Did you happen to check your messages upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: I didn’t see any messages.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: When your phone blinks, it means you have messages.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Sorry. I wasn’t in my room a lot. (winking) Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Well, you have 17 messages.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: A Doug Mannerheim. Then Melanie Mannerheim. Then Melanie and Doug together, crying and singing hymns. Then Melanie again. Pretty much off and on like that for hours on end. Eventually she was just like, “Hi sweetie, it’s just me, Mel.” (beat) She’s crazy. Lamb is touched. Loray was right.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. She signs for the room, tips the clerk and heads for the exit. The clerk looks at the tip?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Hey, what did you play? Did you shoot craps?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (leaving) Pardon me!  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: A Christmas carol A CAB from a RURAL TAXI COMPANY drives up the isolated country road to the Mannherheim’s house. From a distance, see Lamb exit the car. A disheveled Lamb heads up the snow-covered front walk. T house is lit-up and looks cozy and inviting. She pauses to look at the big, illumnated NATIVITY SCENE the front entrance. Yes, it’s plastic and tacky. But it’s also touching. Lamb smiles sadly at the Baby Jesus doll tethered to the manger with a bike lock. Lamb opens the front door. Melanie is passing through the kitchen with a cup of cocoa. She wears glasses and sweatp and looks adorably frumpy compared to her glamorous “chur look.” She turns and sees Lamb.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Oh thank God. Melanie and Lamb rush toward each other. Melanie sweeps L into her arms, her first words summing up every mother’s chief anxiety: MELANIE (CONT’D) Are you hurt? Are you hurt? Lamb's face is muffled against her mother’s shoulder. The both in tears.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No... I’m happy. Doug hurries down the stairs in pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Is she in pain?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: She says she’s happy. Doug’s relief turns to anxiety in an instant.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (worried) Oh no.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie and Doug sit on the couch near the Christmas tree Lamb sits in a chair facing them. Melanie is rapidly tapp her foot on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: You going to talk first?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: If you don’t mind... Melanie’s reply is machine-gun rapid.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Ha, of course I don’t mind. I’ma very generous listener; you know me. All-Ears Mel. She bites her lip impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: What I did in church-- it was wrong. Disrespectful. I had a problem with people shouting their beliefs at me, but then I went and did the same in turn.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Everyone understands that you’ve been through a trial.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: But they must have been upset.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: People tried to talk. But your mother wouldn’t let them get away with it. She would defend you through anything. Lamb looks at Melanie. Melanie looks down.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (touched) Really, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: (quiet) Yes, duh.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 102.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You commited apostasy. Are you prepared to repent before God and the community?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: No. Doug and Melanie are startled by this.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...not before the community. This is between me and God. I know you love your church, but right now I don’t need the stadium-seating and the Teen Club and Christian Talent Night. There’s nothing wrong with those things, but I want to know who I am and what I believe away from all of it. Just me, flesh and bone. Melanie and Doug take this in. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Well, you’re a just a little too old for Teen Club...

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: That’s not my point. I want to go out in the world and act on it. If you stay in a place where everyone thinks and acts the same as you, it’s just an echo-chamber for Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (missing the point) I think the new carpeting really cut down that echo.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Lamb, you may not realize this, but I can be bit of a maverick myself. Remember that sermon about the dangers of yoga and how it subtly encourages the worship of false gods? Well, I thought that was a bunch of bunk. I went ahead and joined a yoga class at the gym. I’ve been going regularly. What do you think of that?  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 103.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Good for you, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: I just change it up a little in my mind. Sun Salutation becomes God Salutation. Down Dog is Down Satan, and so forth.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: We're not stuffy, honey. We’re open to hearing about your new beliefs as long as they’re still extremely conservative.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (carefully) Dad...I disagree with many of the things I’ve been taught. Heavy silence from Melanie and Doug.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Certain things aren’t a matter of agreement or consent. Some things are just God’s word--

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: (heated) Or your interpretation thereof--

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Christ speaks directly into the hearts of our leaders.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Like Pastor Rick?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Hey! Lamb and Doug look at Melanie. Her sharp tone implies tha maybe she’s not totally ignorant of the Pastor Rick incid

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know there’s one thing God hates and that’s sharpened tongues in the home. So let’s just throttle down here and save the arguing for an appropriate time, like tomorrow.  Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 104.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Just-- just let me show you guys this one thing. You’re not going to like it, but just promise me you won't judge.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (suspicious) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: This is important to me. Try to be open-minded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are low. The Mannherheims watch Rudolph the Re Nosed Reindeer on the big TV. It’s near the end. Melanie and Doug are tight-lipped with disapproval, as if they've been forced to watch something racy.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Where did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: The airport, on my way back. (then) It reminded me of a nice time.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Your childhood, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: Sure. They watch for a few beats.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: This isn’t so bad, I suppose. It’s clean. Doug seems surprisingly approving.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You know, at least it celebrates Christmas. (sanctimonious) Not Kwanzaa or Ramadan

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: That reminds me. I got this really cool scarf on my trip. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue (mm/dd/yyyy) 105.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It would look great on you. I’d like you to have it.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Really? Thanks, honey. Lamb is completely straight-faced.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: You should wear it to church.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I will. Lamb snuggles up between her parents. There are certain things that will divide them forever. But for now, they’r together and Lamb is safe. Then.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Are you leaving, Lamb? Lamb stares at the screen. The Misfit Toys, finally appreciated, are being dropped from Santa’s sleigh into t outstretched arms of children.

dialogues.speaker: LAMB
dialogues.text: This is something I need to do.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC UP
dialogues.text: Close on a POSTCARD from Chicago with a photo of the BLUE BROTHERS. “Greetings from the Windy City!” Reveal William behind the bar. He reads the postcard for moment. Then, he carefully tapes it to the wall above his cash register. There are FIVE OTHER CARDS already affixed the wall: New York. Hollywood. Austin, Texas. New Orleans Walt Disney World. Loray sidles up to the busy bar in her sequined “dealer-tainer” finery. William turns around.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Another postcard, huh? The girl gets around.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She’s on a mission from God. (then) I can’t believe they even find their way here. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The address just says “William and Loray, Imperial Palace, Paradise, Nevada.”

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: We've worked here so long we’re on the National Registry of Historic Suckers.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: At least you're graduating soon. Though Loray shrugs this off, we see a glimmer of pride i her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: With my lucrative B.A. in Complaining About Cinema. (then) So where is she now? Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She was, for a time. The she went back to Montana to make things right with her folks. Sounds like it went fairly well. (casual) She mentioned she might want to give Las Vegas another chance.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: I see you trying to not smile. Look at that. You’re like a seventh- grade girl. William turns away, refilling a CUSTOMER’S pint glass.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I’m not smiling. Loray tries to catch him in the act as he bobs and weaves avoid her.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: Yeah, right! I see you cheesing back there. Careful, you might pull a muscle. The EMCEE has taken the stage. Loray finishes her drink.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m up.  107.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Break one.

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the Imperial Palace is proud to present the musical stylings of our dealing diva, Loray! Loray takes the mic.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY
dialogues.text: I think you’re going to like this one. It swings. She nods to the BAND. We hear the tinkling opening notes “Wouldn’t it Be Nice?” by the Beach Boys. Loray begins to sing in her sweet, clear voice.

dialogues.speaker: LORAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be nice if we were older... The CROWD responds favorably, applauding as Loray bounces around the casino with the mic. This is the musical “happ medium” she’s been looking for. William watches her with admiration and affection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb sits in the window seat of an airborne JET. She look more confident and assured than we’ve ever seen her. No longer hiding in shapeless garments, she wears the clo a “normal” 22-year-old woman would wear. Skinny jeans, a hoodie, and a pair of boots. But there’s a small CROSS ar her neck and she still carries herself with Lamb-like dignity. Lamb gazes out the window as the sun melts into the cloud It’s as beautiful as any religious illustration. But it’s REAL. We hear Loray’s voice singing joyfully: Wouldn't it be nice... We don’t know where Lamb’s going. But we know she’s going be all right. THE END.  108.
